Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Answer with no explanation, only 'Increase' or 'Decrease'. data.sampled:
All contracts are for 100 shares. Answer: Increase

The option contract with a higher strike price ($103) is currently in-the-money, while the contract with a lower strike price ($104) is at-the-money. All things being equal, an increase in the stock price would result in a larger gain when the contracts are exercised. Therefore, the an increase in the stock price would represent a 'decrease' in the exercise price.

data.sampled: Answer with option 'decrease' because a decrease in stock price will lead to an increase in your call options' value. Based on the given stock price of $200.34 and current call strike price of $17.75, your call option is worth $16.99. However, with a decreasing stock price in the near future, the value of your call option will also decrease. At the same time, if you had chosen a call with a $280 strike price, your current call option value would be around $18.95. Thus, to maximize return, choosing an option with a decreasing stock price is the more optimal choice.
